questions.stem: California’s Basic Speed Law means:

choices.text: You may always drive at the posted limit.
You must never drive faster than is safe for conditions.
You must match the fastest traffic speed.
You must drive at least 55 mph on freeways.

questions.explanation: The Basic Speed Law requires choosing a speed that is safe for current conditions, even if that is below the posted limit.

questions.stem: At a ramp meter showing a red light, you should:

choices.text: Proceed if traffic on the freeway is light.
Stop and wait for green, usually one car per green.
Treat it as a yield sign.
Ignore it; ramp meters are optional.

questions.explanation: Ramp meters regulate flow. Obey them like a normal signal—stop on red, go on green.

questions.stem: When merging onto a freeway from an acceleration lane, the best strategy is to:

choices.text: Stop at the end of the ramp and wait for a large gap.
Match freeway speed and merge into the first safe gap.
Enter at any speed; others must adjust.
Signal after you begin merging into the lane.

questions.explanation: Use the acceleration lane to reach traffic speed, signal early, check blind spots, and merge smoothly.

questions.stem: Double solid white lines next to an HOV lane mean:

choices.text: You may enter if traffic is light.
Enter or exit only at designated openings.
Treat as a shoulder.
They are advisory only.

questions.explanation: Do not cross double solid white lines. Enter/exit HOV lanes only where permitted.

questions.stem: At freeway speeds in good conditions, a general minimum following distance is:

choices.text: 1 second
2 seconds
3 seconds
Half a car length

questions.explanation: Use at least the 3-second rule in ideal conditions; increase to 4–6 seconds for higher speeds or poor conditions.

questions.stem: When passing a large truck on the freeway, you should:

choices.text: Linger beside the truck to avoid speeding.
Pass quickly and safely; avoid the truck’s right-side blind spot.
Pass on the shoulder to minimize lane changes.
Use high beams to ensure the driver sees you.

questions.explanation: Trucks have large right-side blind spots and create turbulence. Pass efficiently and safely on the left.

questions.stem: The painted triangular area (gore) near freeway ramps is:

choices.text: A legal place to stop briefly.
For emergency vehicles only.
Off-limits; do not drive over or stop in it.
A metered waiting zone.

questions.explanation: Gore areas are prohibited zones for general traffic—don’t drive over or stop in them.

questions.stem: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you should first:

choices.text: Brake hard to slow down quickly.
Steer sharply toward the shoulder.
Ease off the accelerator and keep the wheels straight.
Shift to park immediately.

questions.explanation: Ease off the gas, keep steering straight, and avoid sudden braking or turns until traction returns.

questions.stem: In heavy fog you should use:

choices.text: High-beam headlights.
Low-beam headlights.
Parking lights only.
No lights to avoid glare.

questions.explanation: Use low-beam headlights in fog. High beams reflect and reduce visibility.

questions.stem: To exit a freeway safely, you should:

choices.text: Slow down in the main lanes, then move to the exit.
Signal early and decelerate in the exit lane.
Cross the gore area if needed.
Wait to signal until you’re on the ramp.

questions.explanation: Signal early and reduce speed only after entering the exit lane.

questions.stem: During steady rain at freeway speeds, you should generally:

choices.text: Maintain the same speed and following distance.
Slow down and increase following distance.
Use cruise control to maintain traction.
Drive with only your parking lights on.

questions.explanation: Rain reduces traction. Slow down and increase following distance to maintain a safety margin.

questions.stem: Use high-beam headlights at night:

choices.text: On open roads with no oncoming traffic.
When following closely to better see the vehicle ahead.
In city traffic to improve visibility.
In fog for maximum reach.

questions.explanation: High beams are for open roads without oncoming traffic. Dim them when following or approaching others.

questions.stem: On a long downhill grade, the safest technique is to:

choices.text: Ride the brakes continuously to control speed.
Shift to a lower gear to use engine braking.
Shift to neutral and coast.
Accelerate to avoid brake fade.

questions.explanation: Use engine braking by selecting a lower gear; continuous braking overheats and weakens brakes.

questions.stem: Approaching a stopped emergency vehicle with flashing lights on the freeway, you must:

choices.text: Maintain speed but honk to warn others.
Move to a non-adjacent lane if safe, or slow down significantly.
Stop in your lane until it leaves.
Turn on high beams to increase visibility.

questions.explanation: California’s Move Over law requires changing lanes away from the incident or slowing significantly if you cannot move over.

questions.stem: In a freeway work zone, you should:

choices.text: Follow cones and signs, reduce speed, and increase following distance.
Use the shoulder to bypass slow traffic.
Drive faster to clear the area quickly.
Ignore flaggers if the light is green.

questions.explanation: Work zones require extra caution: follow all controls, slow down, and leave more space.

questions.stem: In extremely dense fog on the freeway, you should:

choices.text: Stop in your lane with hazard lights on.
Pull far onto the shoulder and use hazards only if you cannot exit.
Use high beams so others see you sooner.
Drive with no lights to reduce glare.

questions.explanation: Do not stop in a travel lane. Exit if possible; if not, pull far onto the shoulder and use hazards.

questions.stem: If a vehicle is following too closely on the freeway, you should:

choices.text: Brake hard to warn them.
Increase your speed well above the limit.
Maintain speed and change lanes when safe to let them pass.
Turn on your high beams.

questions.explanation: Keep calm, maintain speed, and create space by letting the tailgater pass when safe.

questions.stem: You are about to miss your exit. You should:

choices.text: Cross the solid line and gore area carefully.
Stop in your lane and wait for a gap.
Continue to the next exit and reroute.
Back up on the shoulder to reach the exit.

questions.explanation: Never cross restricted areas or stop in travel lanes. Continue safely to the next exit.

questions.stem: Strong crosswinds on a freeway bridge begin pushing your vehicle. You should:

choices.text: Grip the wheel, reduce speed, and avoid sudden steering.
Accelerate to stabilize the car.
Turn the wheel sharply into the wind.
Brake hard and stop in your lane.

questions.explanation: Hold the wheel firmly, slow moderately, and make smooth corrections. Avoid abrupt moves that can destabilize the car.

questions.stem: Your vehicle loses power on the freeway. The best first action is to:

choices.text: Stop immediately in your lane and turn on hazards.
Signal, move to the right, and coast onto the shoulder.
Shift to neutral and coast in the left lane.
Turn off your headlights to save battery.

questions.explanation: Signal and move right to the shoulder. Once stopped, angle wheels right and use hazards.
